blocks.text: Based on onset, encapsulation, and necrotic content.
Timing <4 weeks, no wall, homogeneous simple fluid, no solid debris. Typically sterile; supportive care unless complications.
>=4 weeks, well-defined wall, homogeneous simple fluid, no solid debris. Consider drainage if symptomatic, enlarging, or obstructing.
<4 weeks, ill-defined, contains non-liquefied necrotic material/debris. Delay intervention if stable; monitor for infection or clinical decline.
>=4 weeks, well-defined wall, heterogeneous with necrotic debris. If infected/symptomatic: step-up drainage >> necrosectomy.
Gas in collection, fever, leukocytosis, clinical deterioration. Consider antibiotics plus drainage.

items: Acute peripancreatic fluid collection (APFC): <4 weeks, no defined wall, homogeneous fluid, no solid debris.
Pancreatic pseudocyst: >=4 weeks, well-defined wall, homogeneous simple fluid, no solid debris.
Acute necrotic collection (ANC): <4 weeks, ill-defined, contains non-liquefied necrotic material/debris.
Walled-off necrosis (WON): >=4 weeks, well-defined wall, heterogeneous with necrotic debris.
Infection indicators: gas within collection, fever/leukocytosis, clinical deterioration.
Most sterile APFC/pseudocysts: supportive care; intervene if symptomatic, enlarging, or causing obstruction.
Necrotic collections (ANC/WON): delay intervention when possible until walled-off (>=4 weeks) unless infected or causing instability.
Infection: consider antibiotics plus drainage (percutaneous/endoscopic); escalate to step-up necrosectomy if needed.
Document contents (fluid vs debris), size, location, and relationship to bowel/vasculature for procedural planning.

blocks.text: Reference: pcheng.org pancreatic collection guide; Atlanta Classification 2012.
